I bought a DuroMax 10,000 Watt Generator from [...]  Model #XP10000e a while ago and have never had to use it up until now. It is capable of 120 volt operation and or 220 volt operation.Many people have told me that it's not possible to get simultaneous 240 & 120 from the generator but I'm here to tell you that it is possible and works extremely well.After some trial and error I figured out that it is possible to use the single 50 Amp, 4-Pole outlet to achieve a Simultaneous 240 / 120 Volt Wiring Harness.Wire the male 240 V / 50 Amp plug properly. Green (ground) on top pole. Red & Black (hot) go to either of the side poles. White (common) goes to the bottom pole.220 Volt Outlet is wired without a common (white) wire. Connect the red & black wires to either side of the outlet. Also connect the green (ground) to the outlet.Using the white wire, go to the 110 volt outlets. Make certain that you connect the outlets (look on the back of the outlet) to the common pole.Using the black and or red (hot = 120 volts each) connect to the hot pole on the 120 volt outlets. Use ONLY one or the other per outlet or you will have 220 rather than 110.Ground all outlets using the green or bare wire.This is an isolated setup ( No Back-Feeding )and does not connect to any part of your home's wiring. In my case, I drilled a 3/4" hole through the wall and ran the main cable (8 gauge, 4 strand) outside making certain to leave plenty of slack to get to the generator while having enough left inside to make all my connections. I located the 1st connection (220 Volt) very close to the hole I drilled and mounted an outlet box to the wall for the A/C. Then I mounted a larger box beside it, to make my connections. From the larger box I have two smaller boxes connected using 12 gauge, 3-wire, to connect the 110 volt outlets.Check it out and maybe you can help others that have wanted / attempted to use more of the power that it harnessed in a larger generator like this one.I tested the setup with a 220V, 25,000 BTU A/C and several 110V items, including two shop-vacs. With everything going at the same time the voltage needle remained well within the operating range of approx. 220 Volts.Now that Irene is upon all of us on the eastern seaboard, I'm happy that I bought this generator. Even though I have not lost electricity yet, there are 900,000 people all around the area that have.

reviewText: Cheap and won't last very long. Fades quickly in sun and unravels. It looked good when we received it but we threw it away in less than a year.

I bought this unit a little over a year ago to powerwash a 200SF concrete wrap-around porch prior to staining. When the machine arrived it was leaking oil. Amazon was great about getting me a replacement immediately.  The 2nd machine showed promise, though I wasn't as impressed with its performance as the two Husky machines I had previously. Still, it got the job done. I had no other projects requiring its use so I stored it away in the garage until just a few weeks ago.  When I got it out again I found that it would not start.  A handyman friend of mine discovered that the electrical plug was completely corroded inside and had to be replaced.  Once the unit was operating he discovered that the wand had a damaged o-ring which caused the wand to leak. These problems were fixable but I expected better quality and durability from a McCulloch product.  I haven't used the machine yet since its repair but my hopes aren't high for a happily-ever-after relationship with it.

This paper mulch is the easiest, most effective way to control weeds that I have ever seen.  I'm getting old enough to begin to think that a vegetable garden is just too much for me but, with this paper mulch, work in the garden is down by 80-90%.  It's great!

Not sure why the bad reviews!  With all our snow storms this year, and more to come next week, road salt is very hard to come by.After hitting 4-5 local stores, none having salt, good old Amazon brought 2 bags right to my door!Works well and particle size being mixed small-large allowed for continued melting during ongoing snow/sleet.We have a sloped driveway (30 degrees or more) so salt is a must.A little pricey, but worked very well!  Will definitely purchase again.

Here is a tip. When your motor burns out for the second or third time go ahead and replace everything, the motor, the pump and the filter. Mine broke one at a time and I would have saved a lot of money and trouble had I just replaced everything at once. It is not at all difficult to install if you are ok with cutting and gluing PVC.
I now have six.  I purchased several years ago at a home show.  This is a high quality product that should last for years.  They are not cheap but you get what you pay for.  Highly recommended.

I used this to protect grass seed when redoing my approximately 20,000 Sq Ft yard. It was able to speed germination, keep birds from eating the seed, help control erosion while roots are starting and best of all no messy straw to deal with! I used rocks on the edges to hold it down. It was reused 4 times on different parts of my yard and than given to a friend who used it in the same way. I highly recommend using this for anyone planting grass seed!
Was looking for one of these for a while had one and broke.  These work great highly recommend..Will purchase again

We have had this shelter for a year and I thought that this would be the appropriate time to write a review.  First of all the frame is fine...I have read some reviews that are critical of the gauge of the poles but it's quite sturdy.  It has been through a few storms and has not been bothered. The problem is the netting...it does not attach to the frame securely and bugs can get in. We tried velcro on the corners but to no avail.  It's better than nothing for sure, but that was the disappointing part of this whole purchase. I have kids and so far the screen has not ripped or torn but it is fragile. We have been very careful not to rip it...in other words we have treated the screen with kid gloves. This is the shelters Achilles heel for sure. I wish it attached better than it does because it is not a cheap purchase. I hope this helps someone else because I probably would not have brought this shelter if I knew it didn't keep out the bugs very well!
I was looking for something with high quality that would last a while, this is it. The only problem is Jet isn't as strong as Id like, everything else is great.

reviewText: This knife has proven to be quite handy.  I have used it mostly for chopping branches and cutting down small trees.  The knife is built solid and the blade is weighted enough to carry through branches and saplings in one strike.This is a good knife in comparison to machetes and corn knives I have owned and used, but I think because of its size and design it will be much more versatile and useful.

I purchase this and put the batteries in.  About 15 minutes later I picked it up to give to my son it was red hot.  I opened the battery compartment batteries were so hot they were actually melting and leaking a large amount of clear fluid.  It burned like h----.

I ordered my Cobra Pit on a Sunday after reading the reviews, some Good some not so. I was confident I could overcome any problems experienced by a few customers. The Pit was at my door by Thursday evening. I opened it immediately after reading about missing parts. The manifest did list some (20)twenty nuts when only twelve (12)were included.  The missing eight (8)were inserts set into the mesh rim sections. I didn't waste any time figuring that out. It took me forty minutes to assemble. Its sitting on my patio waiting for some marshmellows and heat. It looks impressive and is well built. I'll write back after a season of use but I can't imagine any problems arising.

I've owned this smoker for 4 months and my only regret is that I didn't buy it sooner!!! I grill a lot on a Weber LP grill but until the WSM have never smoked anything. I thought there would be a learning period but it seems like you just cant go wrong with this smoker.
We live in colorado and this item is a staple on our spring, autumn and winter patios.  Love it! Buy it!!!

bar and chain come loose in box. in trying to assemble, the c-clip and flat washer holding the drive sprocket came off. tried to put back but c-clip/snap ring has no spring to it and was stretched. that's why it came off in the first place. will buy new one tomorrow and report back.installed new c-clip and assembled saw. turned on saw and chain jumped off. opened case and found new c-clip had jumped off. looked closely at motor shaft and found groove shallow and rounded. will not hold c-clip. returning unit.see my photo on product page.

Not sure how humane it is to electrocute a mouse, but this thing reminds me of a terminator that came back in time to kill Sarah Connor -- it won't stop until it's target is dead. Well, or at least until the batteries run out.I truly had to chuckle at this thing -- it literally turns mouse catching into an automated process -- mouse steps in -- ZAP! -- then the electrocution chamber rotates, drops the mouse in a compartment, and rotates back into position, ready for its next victim.  A light even turns on when the "drawer" is full -- just pull it out, dispose of the rodents and slide the drawer back in for the next pile of vermin.  I'm not sure who needs a mouse trap that's this efficient and has such a large capacity.  If you have that many mice, it may be time to move!  For my purposes, I put it in the garage, and it did catch the one mouse we had. (Hopefully the only one.)Overall, I think it's pretty good at what it does and is about as "humane" as any other trap.  It's not like any of them safely capture mice so they can be set free in the wild.  Like all mouse traps, it's basically a killing machine.  But at least this one can be reused again and again, and emptied with little fuss or creepy-crawly feelings!  I agree, however, that this may cost a lot in batteries.  But I actually prefer battery operated, over plugging it into a wall outlet.  If you have mice, the trap needs to go where the mice are, not where the nearest outlet happens to be.  It certainly beats those old style traps that always snap my fingers!UPDATE 7/18/11 - Good News/Bad News --- this thing just caught another mouse; which means we have more mice than i thought. Eeeeeeew!
Not more to say than what I've got in the title. It's so easy to use that my mom trimmed a lot of the hedges.

reviewText: This part fits very well and is easy to install. In my case, the gas tank did not need to be removed; I just removed the bottom two screws from the starter and it slipped out. The top two screws are just locators. The warning is for the plastic cap, or dust cover. It does not snap over the flange like the original, so I superglued it like others had suggested. Unfortunately, it fell off after one use and got wedged against the flywheel, locking up the engine so it wouldn't start with either the pull or electric starter. Had to remove the pull starter and fish out the cap by hand to loosen it up.I'm going to look into the Ariens cap that was mentioned in another review, but for now I've left the cap off and I'd recommend others do the same.

Great company and will recommend to people in the future!

reviewText: I compost, recycle, reduce, reuse, buy recycled products, use flourescent bulbs and will be trying to install solar panels soon. Not a granola, just trying to be responsible about my life. So, the next logical step in my garden would be to stop using sevin dust and use an ecologoically responsible pesticide. Well, I am going back to sevin dust. My beautiful garden was destroyed overnight. My hubby sprayed this "pesticide" to my corn, squash, sweet potatoes, watermelon, and pumpkins. Woke up this morning and my corns are laying on the ground. No rain last night, so they were not blown over. Went to take a look and the corn has yellow stalks right from the middle down. Exactly where the insecticide instructed us to spray. The pumpkins have splashes of yellow where the insecticide landed on the leaves, the squash leaves are laying flat on the ground instead of springing gaily from the stalks witht he same yellow splashes. The last 6 weeks of work was for naught. Will be contacting the company and banging my head on a corporate beauracy for naught also. BTW, found a beautiful, healthy caterpillar laying next to a corn stalk. Looks like something survived...
I mean its an Oregon chain, and the proper one, at the cheapest price ive seen, especially ordered with another item so you qualify for super saver.

reviewText: I picked this up for my Dad, who actually uses it as an effective & humane way to catch cats that trespass thru our yard (we raise rabbits.) This live trap is large enough to capture cats and quite possibly a raccoon & has been an effective way to protect our own critters while harmlessly catching potential-wannabe predators and either a.) returning them to their owners with an "I told you so" (for some reason nobody thinks their cat EVER leaves their yard.) or b.) strays are turned over to our local humane society - and they are Awesome by the way for cleaning up, giving shots & putting these animals back out for adoption.Easy to set, bait & clean up this is a great trap for dealing with a problem in a humane way.
Very happy with this purchase and customer service. This is quality material and stands up well and looks wonderful. Am extremely satisfied.

After reading all the reviews I was excited but skeptical about buying. Upon arrival I find out the bulb is busted. I know Amazon sells bulbs. Once I notified them I was told I couldn't recieve a replacement bulb. Wow! I have to pack my whole fixture up and send it back and wait on another. Making wait longer. Once I expressed my displeasure with their customer service I received and email saying don't worry about it we will send you a replacement bulb. That kinda cheered me up. Then the next morning Amazon sent me another email saying they are sending out a whole new fixture and still want me to return my old one when I had already expressed that their is nothing wrong with my fixture. Said they will be charging my card again for the new fixture. Now that had my blood boiling. I already told them that if I had to send anything back it would be everything and I want my money back. Amazon does not value the customer. Never have I felt so disrespected in my line.
summary: Idk if it works or not

reviewText: Grill covers are not exciting, or at least not to anyone I know.  All you want is something that works and will last.  This has held up better than the Craftsman one I purchased with my grill.  As an added bonus it is healthier for you and the environment as a whole since it does not contain lead.

I bought this after trying other brands for Budworm on my petunias.  I had sprayed numerous times with the recommended product that they use in my area for these pests, with no visible effects.  After a month of no relief from these destructive pests, I googled Budworm and came up with a video of a nurseryman from the Portland area with rave reviews and with a eco friendly, pet friendly stamp for Deadbug Brew, so out of desperation, I ordered it.  After the first spraying of the product, my petunias started to bloom again within  days.  Within 1 1/2 weeks, they were totally covered in blooms again.  I saw some signs of the budworm again after another week in just a small area, so I sprayed again.  I have eliminated the little monsters, so I am a firm believer in this product.  The product came sealed in plastic, so that if the product had leaked during shipment, it would have been contained, but all arrived in tact.  Hooray for Deadbug Brew!
Seeds came quickly and with no hassle. I have planted them and waiting for them to grow. Hope they are tasty.

reviewText: GREAT SPRAYER: Worked right out of the gate, no problems, this is the third sprayer I have purchased the best.

We have a 4 acre lot that was originally a potato field.  We have worked long hours to turn that into a nice lawn area.  We still had some patches that were rough and needed a roller to help smooth that out.  This product worked great, easily pulls behind the 4-wheeler and when empty is very light and easy to store.

No Bells and Whistles here. No fancy colors. Just pure performance. Similar products at the local hardware stores cost almost twice as much. I am not sure why amazon is selling this for less than twenty dollars.This is my third Corona product - I'm impressed with the other two (shears and pruner) and this lopper impressed me yet again. It has a mighty long handle and a mechanism to further increase power at the blade - what Corona calls a "power bearing". One can now cut tall branches and even thick branches with ease. Granted that my tool is still new, but the cutting performance was almost like slicing through butter. My other two Corona tools have kept up their sharp edge quite well after a few months of moderate use.The aluminum handle also keeps the lopper light making for fatigue free handling. I'm glad I bought this..Only con is - must be kept away from children - or they will be slicing their fingers or worse. This tool needs a locking mechanism.
summary: Yet another Corona product that is well made and functional

When rats and mice first showed up in our house, our efforts to get rid of them started right away.  First we tried the rat baits and glue traps.  Rat baits killed one mouse and the others eluded the glue traps.  Then we tried the tried and true bait leading to a trash can setup and nothing happened. After a while of failed attempts, I brought the Rat Zapper.  I followed the instructions and nothing for a week or so.  So we moved it around every couple of days and kept on changing the bait in the Rat Zapper.  Then finally we got our second and unexpected third rat on back to back days. Amazingly they went for a combination of onions, potatoes chips, and dried dog food. Yes, this thing actually works and works well.  You may have to keep moving it around a bit to possible spots but eventually you'll get your little vermin(s).

For the past four years we've been experiencing some problems with deer in our neighborhood and have been frustrated to come outside on spring and summer mornings to find raspberry plants eaten, ash and vine maple trees nibbled down to nothing and geraniums eaten as soon as they bloom.  My husband did some research and read about the Bobbex spray so we decided to order a bottle to try.  It is definitely working, but the smell for the first 24 hours is truly disgusting.  The trees are still intact though, so it seems great overall.  One issue that we've found on the vine maples is that the leaves seem to be a bit disfigured after using the spray three times.  We obviously do not use this on our raspberries, but two of the water scarecrows seem to be doing the trick for that issue.
summary: Works, but stinks to high heaven!

NickinDallas hit it on the head with his review. I had the identical experience.  The product looks promising with its flowered metal design, swiveling arm, and attractive antique bronze finish. After mounting it to a brick wall with my own mortar/concrete screws, I am hopeful the swivel arm will hold the weight of 100' of 5/8-inch rather heavy rubber hose, although I am not confident. As in the video provided by NickinDallas, the plastic POS clip which is supposed secure the water input spigot to the hose reel did not even hold while removing the hose reel from its packaging. When turning on the water for the first time after installation, the spigot immediately popped off the hose reel spraying water everywhere. The clip is necessary to secure the spigot, and I will try wiring it into position as another reviewer mentioned until I find time to make some sort of replacement piece. But for the money this product cost, why should I have to spend my time fixing it?!
summary: Promising Design Ruined by Inferior Chinese Manufacturing

These look and are described exactly like a pair of steak weights I bought in a commercial kitchen supply shop about ten years ago.  They are generic made-in-China products, but they were the premium choice over a slightly cheaper product the store was selling for the same purpose.I volunteer in the church kitchen for a youth basketball league we run, and I cook all kinds of food on a commercial stove with a big grill, particularly hamburgers and other short-order food.  This will help with your hamburger cooking, and it will help with flat bacon preparation.These are cast iron - they get real hot from the grill and they help things cook faster and stay flat.  Put them on the grill when you light it, and they'll be ready when the grill is ready.I've had these for years and the wooden handles are a smidge loose, but they work fine.  The square pattern cut into the face of the weight allows juices to run out and sometimes leaves an interesting mark on the meat.  They are a zip to clean with a brush.I haven't broken one, but I imagine they'd break easily if dropped since they are cast iron.Keep them oiled or they will rust.
summary: Very nice commercial quality steak weights

I did not have a good experience with IPI. The quick-connect fitting provided to connect the cap to the gas tank did not seal and quickly dumped pint of fuel on the floor when I disconnected the tank to reposition the generator. I contacted Acme Electric Motor, Inc. the vendor who sold the product to me and was informed that they had no warranty responsibility and gave me IPI’s phone number to request help. I called IPI's phone - busy, so I went to the IPI website and filled out customer support form online submitted it but did not receive any confirmation that my support request was received. I waited a few days more and then tried the phone number again. This time a fellow picked up right away. I told him my problem, he assured me he would correct the problem and would send me a replacement quick-connect fitting right away. I'm still waiting. My advice is don't buy IPI's Berg system. Even though it seems to be a simple system, the company does not seem to have a working quality control system in place. And of course the potential for a serious accidental fire makes this product a very bad choice. My advice, don’t open it, send it back ASAP.
summary: Poor Quality and non-existant customer service

This tape sticks to ITSELF much better than to copper pipe. The amount was ample for 15 feet of heat tape (I know it is confusing, but the heat tape is the black plastic covered heating element that this tape I am reviewing positions against the pipe to be heated). I applied it every six inches (sometimes 4 inches on pipe curves) and even had some left over.This tape has a backing. This paper backing must be removed prior to applying the tape to the pipe. This can be tricky in a crawl space because you have to pull each tape section (precutting sections makes applying easier and can be done before you get in the crawl space) off the backing and then apply it to the pipe and heat tape with the heat tape firmly against the pipe. It's impossible to do that with gloves on (you need the gloves for the insulation application later on). Make sure you circle the tape over itself to make sure it won't lose it's grip.Remember, the tape is the device that keeps your electrical element (heat tape) up against the pipe! If your heat tape has large gaps where it isn't touching properly, you will use more elctricity because it will take longer for the pipe to get to 45 degrees and the heat tape will wear out sooner because it's on more often. Don't skimp on applying this tape!Finally, do some math on the length of your pipe and how many strips of tape to precut BEFORE you get in the crawl space. Take the tape sections and the rest of the tape and some scissors in a small plastic bag with you. Everything you can do before you get in there helps.I'm 65 and was still sore for about three days after the job despite a lot of preplanning.

I have large front and backyard lawns, and one full battery charging gets me through both lawns. I have been pretty rough with this mower, in terms of accidentally mowing over rocks and dirt, and it's been just fine. I love how quiet it is, and I do not miss breathing in gas fumes. Highly recommend. Probably my favorite Amazon purchase ever. Now if all my neighbors would just buy it, I wouldn't have to hear their noise pollution.

reviewText: This appears to be a very nice deck box. Unfortunately, it was delivered with a warped lid. Okay. Mistakes happen. However, when I called the number listed for the "Customer Service Department," I was disconnected once and then spent more than 20 minutes on hold before giving up and logging into Lifetime's website.At the website, I found a "contact us" section where, after filling out and emailing the requisite form, Lifetime's canned response says someone will contact me in "2-3 days." Twenty minutes on hold? "2-3 days"? Are you kidding me?I don't know whether Lifetime has a high volume of complaints or a low level of commitment to customer service. Either way, my experience does not inspire confidence in the company or its products.I should add that assembly of the lid literally requires a ratchet plus several other tools and sizes of tools. Also indicative of lack of consideration for the customer.

I can't think of anything I don't like about this yard tool.  I have a yard full of dandelions, and I had been using a small hand tool, which worked pretty well, but required that I either stoop or kneel, and if it was a plant with deep roots, it took some exertion, which I try to avoid, as I have a rib cage injury.  I read the product information, then many of the customer reviews, and I easily decided that this item was worth a try.  Honestly, I am so glad that I did, because it has made my life so much easier.  Most of the time, I can center it on the flowers the first time, then stepping on the peddle/lever closest to the blades, the blades will sink into the dirt quite easily.  It doesn't take much force, and you'll be able to feel that the blades have gone all the way into the dirt, and then you can immediately pull up on the handle, sliding your foot down to the end of the peddle/lever as you do so, and it's out, usually roots and all!  If you go off-center, you can usually repeat the process and extract the remainder.  It's actually kind of fun for a while, and the only time I have a problem, is when the dandelions grow in a cluster, then it sometimes takes me a little longer to judge their centers, but that's not the fault of the tool.  Because I'm using my hands, with the aid of my foot on the pedal/lever, there's kind of a pivot action going on, which eliminates all resistance on the part of the plant, so there is no exertion on my part, and nothing to bother my injury.  I would highly recommend this product.

Instructions are 1 page with a couple of photos, leaves a lot to be disired.studied them for a hour or 2 looking at the parts, assembleb the end piece'sand sliped them on the shaff, then looked at the 2 collars on the shaft, they are put on in the factory, backwards, there is a grove in them to slip over the bearing that has the grove pointing out wards it takes a 1/8 allen wrench,  lossen them but could not move them by hand, had to tap them with a small hammer, turns out after I got them off the allen heads set screw indented the steel roller axle, had to take a file and grind these marks off before i could move the colars, then it had the left side bracket that is bolted on 3 3/8 and the right 3 5/8, I used one pair chanel locks to hold them moving them until they were square, this was the easy part, got them square and drilled them, I made the mistake of locking those collars, leave them loose until you bolt the left and right brackets in place, made the mistake of putting the bolts down where I bored the holes, had to change them later, couldn't get the outer brackets in because the ones that had to have holes bored for interfered by sticking down in the way so put the bolts in from the bottom nuts on top. so you can get the bolts that go thru the side brackets side ways,you can slide those locking collars all the way in and still put the roller on, and the roller will move back and forth to line up even on both sides .the right hand bracket is really tuff, the deck roller is right in the way, I should have taken this off, it would have been a lot eaiser, they say it would be easier to take the rear wheels off,, you can't judge how high to set the left and right brackets because if you set the deck for 3 1/2 inchs them if you take the wheels off you better not have the mower jacked up more than a 1/4 higher than it set with deck from the ground.  take that right side deck wheel off, will be a lot eaisersum it up, put the bearings in the side brackets, move the whole assembly in place and line up one side bracket mark it how high the side bracket is on the support bracket, slide the roller out and put the side you maked on and then the other using the same height, now you can slide the roller and move it back and forth to make even in the bearings then lock the 2 sliding collars in place and lock them down, when its right the roller axle is all most even with the outside bracket.you need 2 ea 1/2 wrenchs, 1 allen head 1/8 inch and 2 ea 9/16 box ends and a scocket with 9/16 with a 4 inch extention that will help on the left side bracket, the right I had to use 2 ea 9/16 wrenchs turning the nuts a 1/4 turn at a time.add says it adjusts easy to change heights, Sure if you have a hour or so.parts are good quality, just a bugger to get on, I planted all of the seeds in the packet in one tray, applied heat from below with a seed germination mat, and covered the flat with a plastic lid. Five seeds germinated and two of those did not root. I have a flat with three plants and the rest of the pods are empty. I seeded approximately two to four seeds per pod so edge effects and inter-pod differences in climate control are very unlikely since not one pod germinated more than one seed. I.E. if it were a climate control problem any pod that produced 1 germinated seed should have seen germination from every seed in that pod. This was not the case. I had two germinated at pods on the edge of the flat and three in the middle of the flat. Two of the middle plants did not root.I did not check to see if there was PLS (pure live seed) test results on the product description. I won't purchase seed without a PLS test again.

This grill I installed on my hot dog cart so that I could shift our business to backyard barbecues.First off the issue that I had that may not be an issue at all to others. It came with 3 grills and a griddle. I did not need the griddle because I needed more grilling surface. To change it over to be all grills cost me over a hundred dollars. There are only a few sites that sell the accessories for this grill and it took me about a week to find the grill and the diffuser that goes under the grill plate.Now for grilling. This grill is so impressive. It cooks evenly and thoroughly. I did 3 events this summer each with over a hundred or more pounds per event all cooked on this grill. It never skipped a beat. It is large enough to place about 25 or so chicken breasts on at once. The cover is solid and balanced so that opening and closing is easy. Also efficient, I cooked for hours at a time I would say maybe 15 hours or so with it on full or medium the whole time and I only went through 1 tank.Pros:+ Great quality construction+ Comes with Natural Gas conversion for free for using it in your home (deck).+ Efficient+ Cooks evenly and thoroughly+ Easy to cleanCons:- Comes with one section being a griddle which is fine but it does not come with a diffuser under that griddle so you need to purchase another.- Lost a knob a day after I purchased (probably my fault but double check them)Overall this was a great capital expense for my business and should make you a nice backyard BBQ grill or even use it as a built in.Thanks for reading my review.-
summary: This this is a beast of a grill.

reviewText: Bought this one to use as a smoker for my Char griller 2121 grill. Like other Char Griller products, it is made with good materials, but the paint is cheap. It already cracked and lost several pieces when the package arrived. The bending of the metal is not a good job, it is not round enough. When the lid is off there is about a quarter inch gap between the lid and grill body. I have to have the lid re-bended to prevent heat loss.After 1 months the paint is already gone in lots of the areas because it does not tolerate heat. I repaint it with high heat paint and it's fine now. Overall is a good grill, Char Griller just need to do a better machining and painting job.
summary: Char Griller can do a better job

I have the 13KW unit that is sold by Lowe's home centers but is still a Generac. It came with the switch, leads and pad. Mine Is setup for natural gas. It is close ( 3 ft or so) behind our house as code required. The unit is now 2 years young and works great. Sure you can hear it running but it is not that bad, especially since it comes on seconds after a power failure. No more house full of flashlights and extra batteries or having food go bad. It is large enough to handle our Ac unit. We've had about 7 or 8 times where it ran for at least a few hours and once for 3 days.Maintenance is easy since the oil filter and drain are easily accessible. My only wish would be for hydraulic tappets since the solid ones that it uses must be adjusted. The front is easily accessible while the rear is a bit of a stretch. All in all a few hours work at a lazy pace.I also purchased extra main fuses for the main switch panel (yes cartridge fuses) and also for the single auto type fuse on the outside unit - but I have never had one gone bad. They are just more peace of mind.Lastly I will talk about Generac service. It came with the side door lock jammed, one phone call and the new one was here in a few days. I have since called them a few times with questions, mostly about maintenance and they were always professional. If my next house needs an emergency generator then I WILL buy a Generac unit.

I've been using this product for years. Yes, it does help in killing and controlling termite infestations. This is only a tool to kill and control the termites outside within the grounds around your home. You will also need to kill the nests within any wood structures as necessary...I recommendOrtho Home Defense Termite & Destructive Bug Killer - 32 oz. 0194260to treat and kill colonies in walls, floors and window frames. Look for toothpick sized holes dispersing wood particles. You may have to drill the hole larger and saturate with termite killer. I use a garden pump-sprayer with termite killer mixture and spray directly in the termite holes. Holes should be filled with caulking or re-plastered & re-painted to seal in termite killer. The killer should remain effective for years.I have a small apartment complex that had a serious termite infestation. I initially hired a professional which eliminated some termites but the infestation arose again the next year. When I called back for warranty re-treating, the professional did re-treat the areas originally treated but stated any other areas are new colonies and not covered by the warranty. Rather than spend hundreds more for a new treatment, I chose to educate myself on the life of the (btw blind) termite.Termites can live 25 years and must start a nest with two asexual termites. One becomes the male and one becomes the female queen. They reproduce drones with one purpose, to feed their queen. She remains stationary within the nest and can become 25 times larger in size...a real fat mama! If her male partner should die, one of the drones gets the privilege to be her new sexual boy-toy.Anyway, I learned subterranean termites need moisture to live and reproduce. These termites feed on plant/tree roots and then swarm (usually in seasonal hot weather) outside the ground and travel to nearby wood structures to form nests. These are the termites that destroy your home. These are the colonies that, most importantly, need to be controlled and killed.If you get the picture, the termite stakes are used to control and kill the subterranean termites outside your home and the spray mixture is used to control and kill the nests within wood.When I first used these stakes about 10 years ago, there was no "pop-up" indicator. I just know these were working since the swarms dissipated. These stakes last about a year killing termites unless there is an excessive amount of water washing away the chemical. Still, within the ground, the chemical helps kill termites. It did take me two (15) stake treatments in the course of 18 months to get the subterranean termites under control and several spray treatments in the various apartments and wood structures around the complex to get control of the termites. Now, I just watch for any new nests and treat accordingly.In closing, this product works to help kill and control termites.
summary: Subterranean Termite Killer...Helps to Kill/Control Termites & Ants

I got a pair of these for the New England Tough Mudder (6 MAY 2012). I trained with them all winter, in and out of cold water, carrying crud, in the mud, climbing ropes, etc. They have a GREAT grip (when dry). When these things get wet, grabbing onto metallic objects will be more slippery than going bare handed. For monkey bars in the TM, I'd suggest taking these off. I did and got right across. For going over the walls and up the quarter pipe, these things rule. I've also used them for minor construction projects and they are pretty good, protecting my hands and reducing vibrations from sanders and the like. One odd thing though, for me, the thumb fits a bit odd. I've had two pairs of these, one large, one medium, and the area between the index finger and the thumb feels short and tight, as if made for people with really short thumbs. Strange, but not necessarily uncomfortable, and will stretch out it seems after a while. People with super large hands will want the Large/X-large size.Pros: EXCELLENT grip when dry. GREAT fingertip protection. Good knuckle protection. Light and responsive. They also drain pretty well if you open and close tight fists, the water comes right out. Really inexpensive. Decent grip with organic material (ropes, wood, etc) when wet.Cons: Can be hard to take off when wet. Slippery with metallic objects when wet. Grip surface can wear out pretty fast.Bottom line: These are really good gloves and you can't beat the price.

reviewText: I bought a fleet of Eheim Heaters, 25w, 50w, 100w, 125w, 150 watt, all for different size tanks as I renew my interest in aquatic life.  They all seemed ok, until this one decided to shift tank temps from 78 F to 94 F !  Not too good, but I believe that once in a while you need to fuss to find the sweet spot on these things, so I turn it down a few clicks to get it back to the 78 F range.  Keep in mind I'm an old timer and don't give a crap if the "dial number in blue" is accurate, no need for me to calibrate, once I find 78 degrees F I'm happy period, no need to fuss with a calibration ring.  Anyway, the heater just went ballistic a second time up to 96 F. I have three other tanks in the room with Eheim heaters, this one is not in the sun, they all are the same and the others are just fine so far, but now I feel like I have to watch them because this one is bad. It's a hospital tank, I have a $75. Aulnocara in treatment in it.  He didn't die, but I'm not happy going back to my Supreme heaters from 30 years ago to keep the tank stable, when I just bought a half dozen new Eheims.  I'll call customer service, it is less than 6 mos. old.  I'll update this review.  I hope they stand behind their product without a song and dance here.
summary: Not too good, but I believe that once in a while ...

reviewText: This is my second, the first is still working.  I gave it to my daughter so I could get the stainless steel model.  I cook on it two our of three evenings.  There are certain settings I use on the three burners depending upon what I am cooking.  The temperature is always exactly where I want it when I set the burner dials. Wow! What can I say about this thing? I truly enjoy cutting my grass. I don't have to maintain gasoline in my garage for a heavily polluting mower, my grass looks like it's been cut by scissors, and it's quiet. As long as you don't let you grass get heavily stalked, this thing chews through the job.Update:I've had this mower for a couple of months in an extremely patchy lawn.  Overall, I'm still pleased with it, but it has a few catches.1. Adjusting the blades seems to work best for me when I don't loosen the screws holding it all in place.  Just turning the adjusting screws works best for me.2. The springtime stalks that shoot up quickly from my grass are hard/impossible for this mower to deal with unless they're kept short.3. This mower does not deal with debris well, as mentioned in the manual.  I have hit some utility marker flag bits left behind and it sounds painful for the mower and causes some gouging of the blade.That said, here are its great qualities:1. My shoes don't turn green.  Seriously, the cut of this thing is like a pair of scissors.  It's supposed to be the fastest healing for the grass, and doesn't cause so much browning.2. It's quiet.  I've cut grass at 6AM without upsetting the neighbors.3. No pollution.  Seriously.  Lawnmower engines have tended to pollute more in an hour than your car driving 600 miles.  This thing only requires the energy you put into it.4. It's not that hard to mow.  I think a non-self-propelled rotary mower is probably about as difficult as this thing to push around.

We bought a 16ft Intex Ultraframe last year and spent the entire summer rinsing and replacing cartridge filters and generally accepting a cloudy, sediment-y pool. Our well water is fairly hard and has enough iron to color the water. We used an iron out product and plenty of chlorine products but felt that the filter was our weak link. So this year we decided to upgrade (from 1200 gpm cartridge to 1600 gpm sand filter) and after only running it for a couple of days we are amazed at the pump power and clarity of the water.The setup was quite simple, we used the inlet and outlet mounts from the original pump (as they were identical) so we didn't have to lower the pool level. Basically filling the kettle with sand and fastening all the piping and control valve. Backwashed and rinsed new sand as per directions and started filtering within 10 minutes.After running for about 6 hours we needed to backwash (pressure gauge shows when it is needed) as our pool water was new and we had iron sediment to clean out from our Sequa-Sol treatment. Started to backwash and could not believe the "ick" that came out from the filter. Once it ran clear, we switched off and back to regular filter. The discharge power was back as strong as could be.This filter is amazing. Any doubts/concerns that we had about the expense being worth it are GONE. Cartridges are $5 a pop and we'd be lucky to get a week out of one, plus the original filter/pump was not keeping up anyway. This unit will pay for itself in only one summer and our water will finally be crystal clear.
these replacement brushes are getting hard to find mine seem to last about a summer then need to be replaced .

You get what you pay for. Well worth the investment.We love this furniture. It looks about as realistic as it possibly can and feels great to the touch. Shortly after acquiring these we came across a similar competitive product at a local garden center that was more expensive and clearly "plastic" in it's look and feel. The Highwood products are clearly superior and it validated our feeling like this was money well spent.There is no assembly required for the table.  It integrates with the chairs extremely well.  Folds nicely for easy storage  They look great and best of all - completely maintenance free!We are extremely satisfied - would buy again and highly recommend.

I was tired of buying a disposable grill every three or four years and I was tired of running out of propane in the middle of the burn. So I went hunting for the best all-stainless natural gas portable out there, and I think I found it. For starters, the parent company, Onward Manufacturing, has been around about as long as me and has grown and morphed into one of the major contenders. They make and distribute other brands including Weber, but the Imperial line is the hands-down winner based an cost and features. And they're made in America.Everything except the cart box is solid stainless, including the double layer hood, the burners, reflectors and grates. It comes partially knocked down but is easily assembled with a #3 philips in about an hour. The instructions are all pictographic, so you don't need a degree in engineering to understand them. It comes complete with a back burner and rotisserie (both easily removed), three large drawers and even interior lights. The natural gas flex line and connections fittings are also included. I really don't think you'll find such a complete package until you approach the $2,000 range.My first few uses have been modest in scope, but the performance seems fine. There's a little front/back heat difference, but that's pretty common. The heat retention with the hood closed is impressive. The rotiserie roasts low and slow as you'd hope. Two large chickens took about an hour and were eavenly done.The $50 cover is worth the price, custom fit and heavy duty.

things you don't want to.  I got these for scorpions but today caught a lizard on the patio.  Baby oil got him loose and he seemed unharmed.  I'm just repeated the warning on them, don't place them where a pet, bird, even a baby could find one.  Goof Off also seems to release the glue.

I bought this solar panel to take with my family camping. We just camp in a tent but that doesn't mean we can't have a solar panel. I use this solar panel to charge a small Deep cycle battery. The solar panel can run it directly, but I want to have air conditioning if the sun isn't out. I use this solar panel in conjunction with the Solar Charger Controller, that I also bought on amazon. works great and runs the swamp cooler like a champ.

We were becalmed in a sea of german roaches.. Ok.. not a sea but it was pretty bad. They were in the microwave, the dishwasher, walking across "clean" dishes in the cupboards and drawers.. they made comfy homes in the knife blocks. I was at wits' end.. so I ordered a tube of Maxforce as a last ditch type of effort (you know the step before flamethrower) (I mean really.. I had geckos living in my silverware drawers to eat the bugs -.-) And I followed the directions and its 2 weeks later.. I have not seen a living german roach in about a week. Used to be I couldn't set a cup of coffee down and look away for 2 minutes without having 2 or 3 bodies floating in it.. This stuff is AWESOME .. G.I.R said it best "I love you guys" :D

Don't buy this piece of junk. All it does is aerate your yard and allow the weeds to grow back 10 times thicker.Which is assuming it doesn't break before you can get every weed in your yard.Also the "Limited Lifetime Guarantee"? It's obviously not their "Limited 90 Day Warranty" cause there is no way 90 days = lifetime.After spending hours over weeks and filling a 50 Gallon bin with weeds until the handle became disconnected from the grabber.All this product is guaranteed to do is get you outside for a little bit of a workout.You'd be better off just aerating your yard with a aerating roller, toss down some fresh black dirt and grass seed to fill in the holes, and then spread some combo fertilizer/weed killer all over the yard.Then for exercise you can go for a walk and laugh at your neighbors using the weed hound.

Used sensibly, the handle held up to 50 holes in a tilled and plastic covered row. That's all I needed at the time. I'm a big guy and yes, the handle does some flexing but you know it's on the weak side so don't push or twist on it, that's what the square pipe on top of the cutter is for. Light twisting, in tilled ground, didn't hurt it but don't just wrench it around. It's a well made tool, otherwise, I really like being able to dump the dirt out at the hole for bedding the plant with.
summary: Buy it and use it with some common sense, it'll do fine

reviewText: The other reviewers are right on here. Battery life is terrible (6 hours to charge 20 minutes to run out). Trimmer is powerful enough to trim around my edging, trees, power boxes, deck, rock borders, etc. Don't expect to knock down two foot tall grass in an overgrown ditch. Works perfectly for my needs on my quarter acre city lot. I fully charge both batteries and use one and a half the juice to complete my trimming needs. Haven't used it as a edger as I have other tools for that. I also have to lean over to use it as a six foot tall person.Pros - great for small yard, no gas, no mixing, no starting, good price, two batteries, light, quieter than a gas powered, great for small yard.Cons - short battery life, small unit (have to hunch over a tad), not powerfull enough to tackle large jobs or large yards.All in all, it suits my needs just fine. I will have to wait for a year or two to see if it holds up to decide if I'd purchase another.

Awesome mower..Did have a few issues when arived.Front wheel was rubbing on mower housing, wheel would hardly move, took hammer to it so it would clear, worked fine.Handle latching pin was not seated correctly, took hammer to it, worked fine.On/off drive bar would fall down, when released, took out and bent for a more tight fit, worked fine.Heavy unit, but pulled itself nicely. I have a small front yard 2500-3000 sq ft, and a strip through gardens to the rear. Pulled the hill in back just fine. Except for the issues, very glad I got it..UPDATE June 2013:Had the mower for one full season, now into the 2nd. Have no problems yet runs real nice. I didn't have to do the yearly oil and no old gas to mess with, cool. Never did run out of battery, but my yard is small. I did take off the blade this spring and sharpened with a Work Sharp system-took 10 min. This is one great mower, so well pleased with the cut..

We purchased this Fountain to place in our medium sized pond. Wouldn't recommend this one for a pond with a waterfall. The current from the waterfall keeps it up too close to the waterfall and interferes with the fountain spray. We had to anchor it away from the waterfall so it was no longer free floating. Also you'll need decent speakers. Our Itouch and it's small 3" portable speakers aren't enough to hear the music well with people talking and milling about in the yard. It does what it says, it has dancing water and changes the lights to the music. But, I think this would work better in a large pool or pond with larger stereo type speakers. Overall we like this fountain, it was a good alternative to a pump driven fountain that needed power to run. Just add batteries and float!!
summary: Add batteries for lights and music.

These have a bit of a learning curve to install, but once you get it, installation is a breeze.  Mine came with 4 installation brackets.  The installation manual is suspect.  Other than the manual's recommendation to use strapping as a mounting substrate on your house, I'd recommend NOT using the manual to install.  You're better off mocking up the install to see where the manual's shortcomings are (and there are a few).All in all, these are pretty pricey for what you get.  That said, it's much more expensive to go with a wooden box (at least the 5' size I got...somewhere around 400-500 bucks).Customer service was VERY GOOD to me.  I had ordered 2 of these boxes and one of them had some hidden damage from shipping.  I took a photo of the hidden damage and sent it to Architectural Depot, the reseller for this Mayne product.  They actually had a real person respond to me over email (after an initial boilerplate response) and immediately said they'd be shipping out a replacement, get this, withOUT requiring me to send back the damaged one FIRST.That's good customer service and it turned my 3.5 star review into a 4.5-5 star review (can't do half's on Amazon).All in all, I will buy these again for some other windows in the future - they do look good once installed.

Attention to detail is required.  Read the directions.  Timing and placement is everything.  Stink bugs are not good flyers and need an easy way to climb up onto the green fins on the bottom.  Don't expect them to fly onto them.  Make sure that at least one of the fins touches a tree branch or large surface.  I have mine in an Empress Tree that is loaded with the bugs, and in a week I catch about 15 to 20 bugs per trap.  I plan on moving the traps, as the directions recommend, closer to the house in a few weeks and then eventually in the attic for the winter.I also made a trap using a Pepsi bottle and used "Rescue" attractant and it works, but not near as good.
summary: Each trap good for 15 to 20 bugs a week.

reviewText: My 24 year old son used this the first couple times before I had a chance to get at it.  He said the electric start didn't work.  When I had my chance, I grabbed the instructions and walked through the starting procedure step-by-step.  I couldn't find the choke because it wasn't a slide choke like the instructions showed, and it wasn't in the location shown in the instructions.  Once I found the rotary choke knob and set it, the electric start worked flawlessly.  No problems since.  We have only had 2-3 inches of snow at a time so far, so I can't speak to how it operates in the heavy stuff.  It has worked well in what we have had to this point.
I only gave one star because the way they manipulate you into thinking this carp works. Good job hustling people and selling them bags of nothing

i actually got this kit from Costco so i cant comment on delivery or price.  well i opened the box and everything was packed well which is good because solar panels are notoriously brittle.After assembling the support stand i realized that it is very flimsy and would most likely fall apart when i am trying to mount it onto the roof and the screw holes were wider than the rafters on my roof.  i also noticed the lower support wasnt high enough to properly support the panels.  i wound up welding some extra bands of steel to remedy this as well as welding the lower support on in the proper location.well after installing the panels on the roof facing west it was already generating power even though the panels were facing away from the setting sun.  now on to the charge controller and inverter.  the charge controller is adequate but i wish it had a volt meter so i would know hen to turn off the system when the battery is running low.  the battery connection on the charge controller is kind of small and the other accessories all connect to the battery so it would be best to build some sort of battery box with separate terminals for all the electrical connection.my opinion: the system is decent but i would suggest if you buy it that you should add to it

Wasn't a majot problem since they were on the base and I attached the greenhouse to a frame made fron 2x6 redwood.Moved my indoor starts out into the greenouse Satuday night.  Noon the next day we had a bit of wind.The wind didn't pick up the greenhouse and blow into the next county because of the redwood base it was attached to.However the pressure from the wind broke several of the plastic connectors causing the greenhouse to collape and tossing my plants on the ground.So much for an early start on the season. I did not purchase this mower from Amazon. I purchased it locally from one of the big box stores. Lacking mechanical prowess, I have not determined whether I tripped the fuse by entangling a piece of plastic in the blade, or the charge ran out. Either way, I cut my postage stamp sized urban lawn, hit the plastic, and the mower refused to restart. If you search "other " websites for reviews, you will see some have issues with the key fuse preventing continued (safe) operation or issues with a short battery life. I have two other mowers and have discovered the usefulness of starting fluid and fuel stabilizer.I will be returning to gas mowers, but will keep this monster. If you do not use the self propelled feature, be prepared for a mini workout. The mower has a little heft.Would I buy it again? Probably not considering the price and the size of my lawn.Does it work? Yes, but be advised the manual discourages using this mower to vertically mow slopes (my best falls occurred from this act)or mow wet grass.Some other reviewers mentioned buying another spare battery to prolong operation. I pd $250 for the mower 8/2011. The replacement battery costs $130.Not gonna happen here!BTW my name is not Sam, Amazon!
summary: Fuse key issues or battery life?

reviewText: works great and lasts long. From stihl so it is expected to be great and it does live up to its name

reviewText: For the money, you can't beat it. I have done long cooks, 8 plus hour at 200 degrees and short cooks at 400 - 500 degrees.  My only complaint would be the temperature gauge, it's off about 50 degrees, but I can live with that. If you are looking for an inexpensive way to get into smoking and BBQ that works, then this is the cooker to purchase.

I don't know what the other reviewers were writing about, but these things don't even begin to catch gnats.We've got these indoor geraniums that were brought in from the outside for the winter that also have these annoying gnats. Based on the other Amazon reviews we thought these sticky paper things would reduce the problem. They don't. The little gnats apparently like water so many of them congregate around sinks and bathtubs but not on these sticky notes.Maybe our gnats are too smart for these things.Waste of money.Update 1-15-2014:Although the product wasn't good for us, the company was very good in giving us a refund with no problems.

reviewText: They all sprouted! they sent me 25 seeds, and all 25 sprouted! I now have 25 7 to 14 inch pepper plants and one has flowers!

I have been looking for some sort of planter you could hang on a wall as my cats will eat any plants they can get to. I stumbled across Wooly Pockets and decided to give them a try. I have had them about 3 weeks now and they are well made. I bought the mini which I was able to put 2 small plants into. I think once the plants grow larger and cover up the pocket they will look great. If you purchase these, make sure you follow the set up instructions carefully. You are supposed to soak the root ball of the plant in water before putting in the wooly pocket; I missed this step and just poured some water inside, and then the water started dripping thru the fabric in the front. If you follow the watering directions correctly, they do not leak. I like the fact that they are made in USA using recycled water bottles as well. Thanks Wooly!10/29/12 UPDATE: I have had this product a few months now and I feel like I can review it more accurately now. I really wanted to like this product, but I just haven't had very good luck with it. Initially I watered like the directions stated; about 1x per week. It is hard to water these properly; I realize you are to keep the water to the back side or tongue, but still it either rolls over the top of the soil or leaks thru the fabric easily if you give it a little too much. I thought my home was too dry as the water rolled over the soil so I tried to water a little more frequently but sill no luck. The first set of plants died in each of these; now I replaced one but the other one is hanging on my wall with dead plant leaves in it. I think part of the problem is that I bought the mini size; I think it is just too small for the plant to grow and be watered in properly. Also I wish the front of the pocket was lined as well to avoid and water leakage. Sorry, wooly wish I had a better review.

Being from the wilds of Pennsylvania, we don't grow much sorghum (if any) in our state. I first saw this last year at a fall festival where it had been cut and shocked for decoration, and asked the vendor what it was and she told me. I was hooked and then ordered the seeds through Amazon.I wasn't sure if I should sow them directly in the soil (we live near the woods and animals are constantly foraging) so started them inside mid-April. I planted in mid-May next to our house and they were a few inches tall. Of the 50 seeds I planted, however, only 17 germinated, that's the only reason I'm deducting one star.But all 17 plants grew.. and grew.. and grew. I am harvesting them now and the tallest is 14'. The sorghum has become quite the topic of conversation, too.  As the vendor did, I shocked it around our lamp post and it is just spectacular. The grains have turned red (not quite as red in the picture-- we've had two frosts already so I wasn't sure how much longer I should leave it in the ground).I am definitely planting this next year, if for no other reason than it was just so much fun to watch grow; and the sound of the leaves rustling outside the living room window was very pleasant to hear on a summer's evening.
summary: Amazing results, everyone loves my sorghum

reviewText: No sign of anything growing at all. I put in a pot with wet soil and kept warm in my starter. I put water to damp the soil everyday just like other seeds I had in the starter. When other seeds sprouted, these didn't.
Just what I was looking for.  Perfect size.  Easy to hang.  I would recommend. to anyone.  Not for real flower.  Although I suppose you could line it with something.

First of all let me start by saying that I own 2 Big Green Egg's and I use them all the time. We cook pizza in them all the time as well. For our last party, we wanted to let our guests (30+ people) each make their own personal sized pizza. I have many toys for my eggs, however the pizza stones and rigs that I have now are more for large and deep dish style pizzas, not personal sized. These stones made everything a breeze, and they handle the high heat of the egg with ease. I cooked over 30 pizzas on them and loved every minute of it! Do not wash with soap, just use a scraper and scrape the remains off. If you are a Big Green Egg owner (congrats for owning the best bbq/grill/smoker/oven/etc in the world!) As you may know it is best just to place your stones back in the hot egg and let them cool with the egg, the high heat will clean the stones as well. I will buy more of these so I can cook 4 on my large egg along with the others on the XL. Again, just buy them, they are ridiculously cheap for what you get.
summary: I cannot be happier with this purchase! Do not think twice, just buy it!

Perhaps, but why did they make a product like this, only to be defective? You won't find this explanation in any written material or manual. Even though the "motion sensor" was stopped, still sounds are emitted when passing the unit. The associate said she would replace the unit if the testing she gave to be done by me, failed. It did. But when trying a follow-up email to relate the continuous noise and unacceptability, the email originally addressed from THEIR service department that I simply "replied" to, came back with "Delivery Failure," not once, but twice.There is no phone # to contact this company. Don't buy this product. I'm out $40 + shipping

reviewText: I have always loved carnivorous plants, but I could never find them locally, and the one nursery I frequented always said "they should arrive in a few weeks" and they never would. I patiently searched for 2-3 years before deciding to just bite the bullet an order a plant online - something I'd never done and was a little worried it would be like mail order plants where they arrive looking like a half dead stick, the feedback on this seller was some of the best on the web and that greatly eased my worry.I got my plant in march, the weather in my area was unusually cold but Joel made sure to ship so it would arrive when there wasn't a snowstorm in the forecast. The times I contacted Joel he always answered very quickly, usually in just a few hours.The venus came with more than enough moss to fill the net pot and  I kept the extra incase I ever decided to buy a bare root plant.  My plant didn't like the journey to my cold mailbox and while it arrived green it wasn't long before many of the traps turned brown. Joel assured me this was normal due to the cold, but if it died to let him know. 4 months later and my plant is BOOMING! It never has less than 6 traps and constantly has new ones shooting up!  While I think the price is a little high compared to other CP sellers the customer service alone makes it worth every penny.

reviewText: Purchased my first one 2 years ago for (I think) ~$700.  It worked for a month and quit.  Fortunately for me I bought it locally and the dealer took it back and gave me a new one.  That one worked for almost 2 years or really 8 months of frequent usage (Ohio swim season) and then the Drive stopped working.  A different local dealer got me a quote to repair (required sending back to Aquabot) for a new Drive motor for over $400.I see where I can buy a new one from Amazon for mid $500's and get a new one year warranty (or two if I use my credit card).  I have considered buying other robots, but the ones that seem to work well like this and possibly have a longer warranty are over $1000 and I just don't want to spend another $1000+ for some other robot, when I read many of them fail after a year or two.  Just because it has a longer warranty doesn't mean it won't break.  So I will probably buy another Aquobot Xtreme and keep the first one for spare parts.Part of the problem for repairs or warranty is you have to ship these things that weigh 30+ lbs in a big box at your expense, which just adds to the pain level.Only because I am familiar with this one and liked it's performance (when it worked), I think I will get another one and keep my costs down (for now, until it breaks).  It's a crap shoot, but at least it is made in America.
summary: Works well but does not last

reviewText: This chair is comfortable, attractive and for the price you can't beat it.  Arrived in perfect condition despite the corner of one box having been damaged. Yes, it's plastic but so are the ones you pay $1500 for.  The variation in color is quite nice.  The cushions are much better than you have any right to expect at this price point.  Zippers!  The cushions are darker than they appear on the screen.  Mine anyway.  More beige or tan than off-white. Anyone who complains about this chair hasn't gone looking for outdoor furniture in the past 20 years.  There is nothing this nice or well made on the market anywhere near this price.

reviewText: This really did the job as a gift for my son-in-law---- he needed something to trim about 50 feet of tall bushes--- this did the job nicely and will serve him in the future.

The product fit perfectly into my grill with a little tweeking but the bracket for the spark igniter were different from the original and I had to figure out how to use them.  They were also much less expensive than what I could find at hardware and garden center stores. No instructions at all came with the shipment.

I have an approx. 50'x150' lot with house in center. The normal assortment of suburban trees, bushes, a swing set, raised garden, and detached garage. If I were reviewing the quality of yard I would give it a 2.5 out of 5. It is uneven, has 4-6 varieties of grasses and weeds each equally making up an equal percentage of the lawn. It has a small hill as well. Not the perfect set up for a push reel mower but certainly a perfect test for one.Set up was easy and it took me about 15 minutes. 11mm and 18mm socket are the only two tools needed. You build the handle and attach the small rear wheels and away you go. Mower itself is heavy, in a good way. Handle has several adjustment points and it worked well for me at 6'3" at the longest setting. The mower pushes easily. The blades on mine at least were perfectly adjusted out of the box. In addition to the paper instructions included, there is a video I saw on the Fiskars site showing you how to adjust the blades if needed. Unit seems to be very robust and of a good quality.I set mine to cut fairly high as the grass was longer and I didn't want to leave a trail of long cut grass to rake up. The mower worked very well with grass and weeds with-in a inch or so of the height setting. Stuff that was a bit longer, like dandelion flower shoots or long wispy grass it tended to miss some. Not so much of the grass but more so the dandelion shoots. Overall though it did quite well on all parts of the lawn. The nicer parts of the lawn with the thickest and nicest grass, it did the best on. My neighbor actually came over and looked at it when I was out and commented that it seemed to be doing a very nice job as well.It doesn't cut with the same width as my gas mower and it took my a couple of passes to get the set up right so I wasn't missing a small strip between rows. It also doesn't cut when you aren't push forward so areas under things where you can kind of stick a gas mower and move it around, were a bit harder to deal with. Ditto for going around trees as I found a straight forward motion worked best and going in a circle was possible, just a bit harder to maintain the blade spin. I will just need to weed whip a little more of the yard when using the reel mower. I also never had any problem with it getting an obstruction that stopped it at all, despite my lawn having a some twigs and sticks. That might have been to to the height setting, but I could every so often hear something getting crunched and the mower blades kept on spinning.It is very quiet and less messy then a gas mower. I wore a pair of flip flops and my legs were very clean afterwards and the shoes didn't pick up any green staining like you would see after using a gas mower. Same workout to push around as the gas mower I have (non assisted type) but that isn't a bad thing as I enjoy the exercise. Having done the lawn once now, it did come out looking good overall even if it left some of the dandelion stalks. I do think I will be more prone to grabbing it on short notice and pushing it around to stay on top of things vs. the gas mower just because it is so simple and quiet. It won't replace my gas mower for 100% of my mowings, but it will be doing the vast majority of them going forward. Overall very happy to have it and would recommend it.Update: Have used it three times now without using the gas mower in between. It is doing a great job. Was able to get out this morning at 0730 and get the yard done without worrying about waking the neighbors. Can also talk to my daughter who likes to walk along side me.
summary: Quiet, easy to push, and works well

reviewText: No program disk is included and you are instructed to download the software from their website. So much for an easy setup. You will have to give them all your personal information in registrating the product before they will send you the software via e-mail. You will have to find UPC codes and serial numbers as well. After you install new batteries in the floating sensor and plug the reciever, you will be instructed to wait for the "signal bar" to register full strength. Unfortunatly, I only recieved a signal strength of 68% while holding the sensor near the reciever. Once I put the sensor in the pool less than 15 feet away, I was now getting a signal strength of 53%. It was now transmitting the pool temp, ORP, and PH. There was no chlorine reading, just a blank line. Everything else looked right, but it would now require a 4 hour "stabilization process". The process lasted for two hours and then lost the signal from the sensor and it was in a state of permanent limbo. It's pretty obvious this thing has a poor transmitter with little or no range. I never did get a chlorine reading and I wasted a whole Sunday on this stupid thing. The toll free customer assistance is Monday thru Friday 9am to 5pm. I'll be at work during those times, so that's not helpful at all. There are plenty of calibration settings were you can reset the radio transmission and recalibrate each reading, but it warns you it is only for "advanced users".The idea of this product is very neat, but obviously it's more trouble than it's worth. The final product was poorly tested and some of the working components are not reliable. I wish these companies would realize that consumers want products that work right out of the box. It's just taking up space in my pool and doing nothing.
summary: Don't waste your money! This thing doesn't work!

These arrived in good time and were packed well.  I recently had been seeing a lot of large roaches (water bugs, palmetto bugs, giant cockroaches, whatever they are) in my kitchen, and sometimes my bathroom.  They scare me to death even though I am a lot bigger than they are so I don't want to get too close to them, and I prefer not to use poisons - especially in the kitchen - because of my cats.The Roach Motels worked very well and are so easy to use.  Unlike ordinary cockroaches, the larger bugs are heavy enough that they fall down (but they then stick on the new bottom) when I turn the trap over.  I have read that some cockroaches have evolved so that now there are some which are no longer attracted by the Roach Motels' sweet odor, but luckily, not in my apartment.  It has now been a few weeks since I've seen a roach.  Yay!!

I have several bird feeders (suet, thistle, seed, etc.) in my yard here in Connecticut and I get a tremendous number and variety of birds. I always feel a bit guilty though that I don't pay enough attention to their water needs and it can get hot and dry here by July. I have a bird bath, but I'm not great at keeping it filled. For those reasons, this little water cooler for birds really appealed to me.I have to say I'm more than pleased with the quality and the design. First, it's very rugged and I don't think that, even if it fell from the hook where I have it hanging, that it would get hurt. Also, its very simple to use--just unscrew the base, fill it with water, re-attach the base and (quickly) flip it right-side up and you're ready to go. It's that easy. And the threads are very strong and the dish part screws on very securely.The loop at the top of the bottle makes it easy to hang. I used one of those elongated s-hooks that are used to hang a hanging pot from a branch or whatever and it works perfectly. A piece of nylon fishing line would work fine, too.I really am very pleased with this and I think it will be a hit with the birds (I just put it out today, so still waiting for the first customers). I'm hanging it next to my screened porch to keep the cats entertained. It's nice to find an affordable product like this that does what it says it will do, is nicely made and serves a good purpose. A great gift for your bird-feeding friends, too. I'll post some photos once the birds belly up to the bar.By the way, a few reviewers have said that they have had it up for a while and no takers yet. I suggest posting a sign nearby, pointing to the waterer. (Kidding.) It takes a little while for birds to feel safe around anything new in your yard. They see it, they know it's there, they'll come. If you want to attract them faster, try letting a hose drip into a bucket nearby for a few hours a day for a few days--birds are extremely attracted to moving water. If they think water is in the area, they will investigate more.
summary: This is a great idea, I love it & so nicely made!

reviewText: Received this lovely hummingbird feeder last week, filled it with nectar and hung it in the yard near the red flowering plants that draw hummingbirds. I hope to include a video piece with the review when the birds show up. The antique bottle design is beautiful when the sun shines through it, and is easily filled and with the nicely designed bottom where the birds should visit the little red flowers which are made of metal on a metal lid over a plastic container. It looks snug enough to keep bees and wasps from getting in. My only concern was if the metallic red paint on the flowers is bright enough to draw hummingbirds. And it is, after a mere 5 days in the garden, this morning we had our first customer at this beautiful feeder. I ran to get a camera to capture the promised video, but a dad-gone robin plunked down on the deck railing adjacent to the feeder and the hummingbird flitted off. Not giving up, though. Will be watching and maybe can catch these tiny little birds chowing down at the cobalt blue feeder that is so pretty in the sunlight.
Product was well worth the purchase. Easy to use and very durable. The price was also definetly a good choice. It is a brand that its well known and lasts for a long time.

As stated above, I live in North Central Wisconsin, with all the winter weather adventures that this entails.  This little guy is great for just about anything you're going to need it for.Now that I have an entire winter under my belt with the Snow Joe, I can honestly say that it performed well above what I ever expected from a plastic, electric unit.  We got some pretty impressive snows, last winter, up to 26 inches at a time of wet and heavy snow.  The fist time we got 12 inches, I expected to have to call my brother-in-law and have him lend me his gas unit.  But the Snow Joe handled it.  I had to take two passes to get the full 12 inches, taking about 6 inches, then backing up and getting it clean to the concrete.  But compared to a shovel, or a the hassle and cost of a two stage gas unit, it was great.  It even handled the packed and frozen stuff the city plow leaves in front of the curbside mailbox.  It's so light that if I need to reposition it, I just pick it up and carry it to the next place.  As far as cord issues, I find that this is really no more hassle than you have while vacuuming, and once you work out a system for your particular drive/sidewalk, it gets second nature.  I did store the unit in the house, since it was small enough.  I just put down a garbage bag, with an old towel on top, to catch the melt.  By the end of the 2012/2013 winter, the snow piles in our boulevard were to tall for me to see over, at 6'1" tall, and our mailbox was accessed through a little hole we'd dug into that snow bank.  The Snow Joe had thrown all of it there, including the heavy piles left by the plow.  I worked it well above what the designers meant it to do, I'm sure, but it handled it.  Other than an occasional scratch from the odd rock and a missing sticker, or two, it barely looks used.Recommended, whole-heartedly, by this Wisconsinite, who's happy to no longer have to break his back, shoveling.
